reviewText:
Hey kids!  Remember those 'interactive fiction' Flash games you would find all over Newgrounds.  The ones that mixed poorly drawn still art with click-able text bubbles.  Remember how much they sucked?

Well, they're back, and they're on Steam.

Freshman Year is a two minute long vignette that plays like something made by a 14 year old during summer camp.  Well, that's not completely true.  I don't think I ever saw a flash game occupy a whooping 127MB of hard drive space.  Anyway, you spend all of those two minutes taking Nina to a bar to meet her friend.  While she's waiting outside, a dude starts trying to make out with her.  Then her friend shows up and drags her into the bar.  The end.

1/10

reviewText: Short visual novel expressing an important message. My only complaint is that it ends a bit abruptly, but I did feel genuine anxiety for the protagonist. The art is very well done. I decided to leave a positive review and give Nina Freeman my support because of all the reviews from whiny teenage boys who think video games should be anti-art and conform to a preconceived structure and purpose.

reviewText: Sure it's short but it gets the point across quickly. It is half way between a choose your own adventure book and point and click adventure a la Sierra games in the 80's.\n\nLike others have mentioned they don't get how can you get into a bar as a freshman or why friends are seemingly oblivous to what happened to their own, it's all very accurate to what happens to many young women (and even men) when they leave home for the first time and have to navigate life alone for the first time. I would probably use this to open a conversation about sex with a teen prior to them entering college.

reviewText:
There's no denying this is short. There's no denying it is not a game as such. But I see no ill in something of this type appearing on Steam.

Even though the experience does not last long, it manages to resonate its underlying message with the power of a magnitude 8 earthquake. What I liked about it particularly was the way it portrayed the generation - the flaky friend, the obviously not as confident Nina. It's unnerving. It makes you think, particularly I'd say if you have a young daughter that may one day grow up to be Jenna or Nina.

On the minus side, the storytelling is not as tip top as it could be, and some circumstances that arise I could perhaps not see happening in the overall story flow. However, I certainly don't want to use minor critisms to dilute the subject matter  - that is one thing that remains firm.

What did I take from it? It doesn't matter what, there is no excuse nor reason.

It's free, and because of the game time, you really will not lose much of your life giving this brave effort a try. More in this category please....

reviewText:
Uhhh..
How do I even..
*Sigh*

Art: 8/10
Music: 7/10
Story: 4/10
Message: 0/10

Spoilers ahead.
The watercolor style really sets a mood for this game. It feels kind of immature, but it doesn't come off at sloppy. The uh... animated scene however was very vague. It takes you a minute to figure out what is going on. I got literal chills, and then got a bit red in the face. It makes you sit there and watch the unfortunate events unfold for a very uncomfortable amount of time. The way the game plays is simple enough, you get a story choice (I use choice in the vaguest possible way) followed by some dialogue and then you check your phone. The game gets unhealthily eerie however, as every time you check your phone you are left with silence from your friend, Jenna's side. You are left to question what happened, until it is finally revealed she was just late. Thanks for letting me stew in that one.
While I enjoy the art style, the eerie atmosphere, and to an extent the game, I do not think that the message it sends is a good one. When attempting to re-enter the bar where you and Jenna were supposed to meet up, you are grabbed by the bouncer who was hitting on you for the first half of the game and are basically groped. Jenna shows up after he pulls you into an alley, grabs your hand, and pulls you away, into the bar. If Jenna had not been there you can assume what would have happened, and I think I understand that the game was trying to send the message to be careful when going out with friends. But what worries me is the message it actually sends. After pulled inside by Jenna she remarks along the lines of oh god he's such a creep
date:
you know he tried the same thing with (other friend I forget the name of) they just ended up doing it in the bathroom." And then the game ends.
I kid you not.
It just ends.
It ends you with the message "at least she didn't get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•
recommended: groping is fine though" which is absolutely not true. The "scene" in question has you
hoursPlayed: Nina

reviewText:
I recommend this game for three reasons 1) It's free, 2) it only takes about 5 minutes to play.  Most importantly 3) It can give you a different perspective on how others lives are.

Is it a 'great game' ?  No.  But that isn't the point.   This makes you think and for some of us may give a teensy bit of empathy that is sorely lacking from our lives.

Take 5 minutes, it will make you a better person.

reviewText:
A highly impressive technical feat of a game, with multiple branching paths of narrative that all masterfully collapse into a single homogenus conclusion.
The deceptively simple controls, clicking things once every few seconds, keep you engaged as some clicks are not registered.
The engaging subplot about the drug addict weed dealer had us hooked all the way through!
The game is a full 10 minutes long, which might seem a bit much, but trust us! Once you get hooked by the deep intrigue of texting teenagers, you will stay for the duration!

Definitely a worthy game, and a fine example of what the dye-haired clique indies can accomplish if they really put their minds to it!

And all this made by a team of just three people!

reviewText: This is not game. It's a short story or possibly even a short film. Either way it isn't a game. You're a girl, Nina, and you go to a bar because your friend told you to. Your friend is late and you get sexually assaulted. Then it ends. The player has no agency or choice in anything. That could possibly be the point though, as in the lack of mechanic is there to mirror the lack of choice the character has as well. The feeling of helplessness is mirrored in the fact as a player you cannot help her. But, the problem is, you don't really care about the character. For a short story, short film, art game, whatever this is where the entire point is the story you should have to care about the characters. This game has no back story, no character building, no world building. Nothing. The most you really learn about Nina is she drinks long island ice teas. I think the game relies on the fact you will feel bad because it's a true story. To be fair, I did feel bad through the assault but that has nothing to do with the game. I'm just a human being with empathy and sympathy and I will feel bad for someone who is assaulted. But this game did not truely shape my feelings. Thinking about it, this game relies solely on that ending scene of the assault. Without it the game is nothing. Without those outside feelings, the game has absolutely nothing.\n\nI do not recomend this game. If it sounds interesting to you, then maybe. The game is 5 minutes long, shorter if you're a fast reader, but it holds no substance. I am a person who usually enjoys slow empty short stories where maybe one thing happens and nothing much. In other words, I tend to love vignettes, but this game is just not a well written one. It's just not worth it.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a game, you should probably turn around now. This point and click story has only one good thing: Pretty art. You are pesented with a false sense of choice with typically two options in different screens. One is more of introvert, the other an extrovert. You essentially decide whether or not you are going to wear make-up, and then if you should wait for your buddy Jenna. Inevitably, the bouncer assaults you, which is about the only confronting part of this project. After that, you're traumatised. The end.

Now, it's not that the we should invalidate the story. This is based off actual events. Horrible things happened to the developer. That being said, it's a sort of story that works better as an animation rather than a series of circumstantial multiple choice questions. The person 'playing' ultimately does not 'win' regardless of which path is taken. There is no actual point to offering more than one answer, because the conclusion and the story format is always the same. It also seems a little confusing to offer more than one answer when this idea is autobiographical. If we are invited into her story, it seems it would make more sense to keep this to a single, straight line for the events unfolding. If the idea is that no matter what happens, the character is not prepared for the assault from the bouncer, then perhaps instead of two questions resulting in the same thing, multiple options should have been made available. What if we waited for Jenna to return? What if we got the option to not drink? Of course, that would be breaking from the autobiography of this tale.

My final issue with this is who is the intended audience? I assume it's for everyone. Are we looking to learn the devestation of sexual assault, or are we just meant to sympathise and relate to Nina? I would advise people who are genuinely triggered by these themes to not 'play' this. There's nothing here for someone looking to deal with it to gain any sense of empathy, it's just the telling of a story. With that being said, I have been put into situations where this sort of thing has nearly happened, and this thing left a sour taste in my mouth. If you want to call it art, that's your perogative, but that doesn't really excuse how disappointing this thing was. I like to think Nina is doing better now, but I'm sorry, this just bothered me.

reviewText:
Right off the bat, the first thing I notice is that the game is technically a nightmare.
To explain; the game has a single resolution, somewhere in the 640x480 range. The window can be resized, but the image stays the same. This means you can make the window so small that you can't see anything or so large that black bars cover the right and bottom of the screen. You can fullscreen the game, but it just adds bars to the right and bottom to 'fill up the screen'. It is a technical travesty.
The art is what you would expect from a deviantart web comic and even though the game took less time to play through than it does to review (about 3 minutes), several frames are repeated over and over again.
Taking a page from bioware's book of game design, any choices made will lead to the same consequence, and your selections only sometimes change what people say.
The story revolves around the pink haired creator of the game, Nina, wasting her education sneaking into ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• college bars and getting drunk on her parents dime. After getting pretty druuuunk" and referencing marijuana four times in three minutes (for no reason whatsoever)
date: the creator of the game gets kissed by the bouncer and the player is rewarded by a three frame wiggling animation (which I believe are the two of them groping each other). The author then stares at a mirror for several seconds before wishing she were smart enough to get a real degree at a real university. The game ends.\n\nOverall I have played worse games
recommended: but I have played very few games that are both completely devoid of content and remarkably callus to people who have actually been abused."

reviewText:
This is a short illustrated story that depicts a single night in one person's life. It takes about 10 minutes to read through.

The writing is good and the pacing is perfect. The visuals and audio work well to set the mood and convey emotion.

There is no twist, punchline or moral; no tragedy, triumph or deep philosophical revelation. Anyone can have a night like this, and many people do. Maybe you did too. This is only an opportunity to see the world through someone else's eyes and share their experience. It might lead you to think, feel and understand. And if not, hey, it's only 10 minutes.

reviewText:
Nina's games aren't for everyone, and they don't have to be. This is a story, a short vignette, and a brief but affecting experience. You won't be jumping or shooting or solving puzzles. If you're looking exclusively for something like that, this won't be your kind of thing.

If you enjoy very human stories that express real life experiences, anxieties, and fears in a very honest way, you should give this game a go.

Nina's games tend to express an emotional vulnerability which is rare in any medium, and rarer still in the world of games -- even considering the indie world. Engage with her games while keeping that in mind and you may find yourself surprised at the emotional resonance she's able to evoke.

Some other reviewers have complained about the lack of actual branching despite the illusion of choice. These reviewers have missed an important point. It's natural for survivors of sexual assault to wonder if there's something they could have done differently to avoid the situaton -- maybe if they waited at the apartment longer, or took a different route, etc. The lack of branching here isn't a product of laziness, it's an intentional design decision which plays into the very anxieties the story expresses.


And for the reviewers spewing all the bile: it's not like you paid for it anyway, so what's with all the hate? You said it yourself, it only took a few minutes. So get over yourselves, just because you didn't like it doesn't make it worthless.

reviewText:
Making you feel powerless, this free five-minute painted point-and-click short story of a typical young woman's night out highlights how a low regard for and high level of objectification of women are all too often considered acceptable.

To those who are saying that this game is condoning such behaviour, you are responding emotionally as it intends, but missing that we are being shown the way things are, not the way they should be.

As a side note, while not obscene, this game is not for children. I hope Steam and other online distribution platforms come to implement age verification more thoroughly in the case of free games.
voteText: 8 of 25 people (32%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This is an autobiographical visual short story, rather than a game.  There are no choices to be made, other than marginally different dialogues that don't change the events of the story.  It's very short, but it's also free.  It tells an unsettling story involving sexual misconduct, so if that upsets you, be warned.

The art style goes well with the creepy music and strange pacing.  The effect of the main character always looking toward her phone during uncomfortable scenes struck me as particularly genuine.  How often do we look towards distraction while in potentially embarrassing situations.  The story is told fairly realistically in its portrayal of a awkward inexperienced girl unable to identify the severity of the danger in a particular social situation.  After an disturbing encounter, she is at a loss on how to handle it.

The ending could use work.  It was sudden and offered no closure, but I think this was deliberate.  In real life there would be no closure.  People would continue on as they always did, and the girl would still be at a loss for what to do.  Those around her would take their cues from her and not react in outrage, since she was too stunned to show outrage.  It's interesting how much a criminal can get away with if they just smile and pretend they're doing nothing wrong.  I'm pretty sure that's what happened here, and it was only with reflection that Nina realized how terrible that situation was and how much worse it could have gotten.

To the writer/developer:  Even if this is based on true events, for the purposes of relating the story to others, it would have been a good idea to include some kind of ending text.  All it really needed was a paragraph or two summing up the end of their evening and how life just continued on after that night, regardless of what happened or what almost happened.

reviewText:
I'm going to go through the more technical issues I had with this game, rather than the ones involving the story, since the story has a clear message about it, and I don't want to tread on that.

First off, I rather enjoyed the watercolored art that Freshman Year had, and for some strange reason, very much enjoyed the simple faces on the characters. However, the groping scene, in which is the best I can call it, seemed a bit messy, in which I didn't understand what was going on until the next scene with her being groped by the bouncer. Also, there seems to be no real build up between leaving the bar and the scene itself. Again, it could be a way of showing that these things happen when you least expect them to, but in each scene themselves, you couldn't tell what was happening until after it was all said and done.

Also, one personal pet peeve that most of these games fail to place in, is the feeling of choice. For this story, you have to enter the shoes of the main character so to understand better the feeling of danger that women can face on a daily basis. However, you're strung along, unable to make a choice on what YOU would do in this same situation, taking out the immerson of being a game itself.

Overall, if this was the first game the creators have made, then I believe they have a good jump start in making the dangers to women a more widespread acknowlaged situation. However, in order to do that, a little more work is needed. For a free game, you have nothing to lose when trying it out.

reviewText:
An interesting little game that is exactly what it claims to be - a vignette.  The limited interactivity gives you very little control over the outcome - for better or worse, you are merely along for the ride.  If you measure art by the ability to have an emotional impact on an individual, then to me, this is art.

Highly recommended!  It takes just a few minutes to complete, so even if you don't like it, you've essentially lost nothing.

And it might just give you something to think about.

reviewText: Hard to stomach, but important. It might be short, but it gets across a lot in a very visceral way in the time it has. Trigger warning for sexual assault for those who aren't aware.\n\nI do have one complaint, but that's more about Steam than the game itself - I had to leave the game open for an extra few minutes in order to be able to write this review due to the game's nature. Given the negative review spam the game already has, though, I'm not sure how else Steam could implement the policy for this game to reflect its runtime without inviting more of that.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As digital interactivity grows more common in schools this is a piece that I can easily see included as a discussion starter in any social studies class.

As with Freemans other games it talks about the darker sides of being a woman, a theme that's not very common on steam even amongst the other art games offered in the catalog.

If you're even slightly interested in the emerging trend of using games as social commentary it's a mandatory experience.

reviewText:
Product received for free

A short, personal story.

One of the worst things about sexual harassment and assault (other than, y'know... their existence) is their banality. They aren‚Äôt something that happens only in places and times of great remoteness and high drama, beyond the walls of everyday experience‚Ä¶ they are (at present, though hopefully not forever) a part of the landscape. And it‚Äôs a part of the landscape that many of us never experience and get to look past if we choose.

Freeman has a solid history of using interactive media to capture and communicate true-ringing life experiences: youth and innocent curiosity in 'how do you Do It?,' illness, body image, and anxiety in 'Mangia,' romance in cyber- & meat-space in 'Cibele.' I think my first interaction with her work was ‚ÄòSpace Dad‚Äô from Space Cowboy Jam 2014, which uses a simple game structure to tell a framed story of a young girl imagining what her often on the road trucker father‚Äôs life is like. Deceptively simple, but clearly heartfelt. That is, I think, how I would boil down all of Freeman‚Äôs work that I‚Äôve played so far:

Deceptively simple; clearly heartfelt.
